[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [All CryptoStorage functions] [Key handle lifetime] Are cryptographic key handles properly managed and zeroized after use, or can key material persist in memory allowing recovery through memory dumps or cold boot attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Enum: Storage (lines 19-24)] [Backend privilege escalation] Can an attacker exploit differences in security properties between storage backends (e.g., VaultStorage with HSM vs. InMemoryStorage) to escalate privileges by forcing backend switching? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Enum: Storage (line 20)] [VaultStorage compromise] If VaultStorage is compromised, does the Storage abstraction provide any defense-in-depth, or does it give full access to all cryptographic operations? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Enum: Storage (line 21)] [InMemoryStorage key leakage] Does InMemoryStorage properly protect key material from memory dumps, or can attackers with memory access trivially extract all validator keys stored in RAM? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Enum: Storage (line 22)] [Recursive namespace confusion] Can NamespacedStorage be nested recursively (Box<Storage> containing another NamespacedStorage), and if so, can this cause namespace confusion or bypass attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Enum: Storage (line 23)] [OnDiskStorage file permissions] Does OnDiskStorage enforce proper file permissions on key material files, or can other processes on the system read validator private keys from disk? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Enum: Storage (line 23)] [OnDiskStorage atomic writes] Are writes to OnDiskStorage atomic, or can crashes during key operations leave partially written files causing key corruption? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Line 14: Serialize/Deserialize imports] [Serde vulnerability] Can malicious serde implementations in custom types T be exploited to execute arbitrary code during serialization/deserialization in get() and set() operations? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Function: get<T: DeserializeOwned>()] [Deserialization bomb] Can attackers craft malicious serialized data that causes excessive memory allocation or CPU usage during deserialization, leading to DoS of validator nodes? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Function: set<T: Serialize>()] [Serialization format confusion] If different serialization formats (JSON, BCS, etc.) are used across storage backends, can format confusion attacks cause data corruption or type confusion? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Function: get<T: DeserializeOwned>()] [Type confusion through generics] Can an attacker call get<T>() with a type T that doesn't match the originally stored type, causing deserialization to succeed with corrupted data? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [All KVStorage functions] [Missing authorization checks] Does the Storage abstraction implement any authorization checks, or do all callers have unrestricted access to all keys and cryptographic operations? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [All CryptoStorage functions] [Privilege separation] Is there privilege separation between different cryptographic operations (e.g., can a component that can only read public keys also call export_private_key())? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Function: export_private_key()] [Audit logging] Are sensitive operations like export_private_key() and rotate_key() logged for security auditing, or can attackers perform key theft without leaving traces? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Function: rotate_key() (lines 74-76)] [Version overflow] Is the key version counter bounded, and can excessive rotations cause version number overflow leading to version collision or confusion? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Function: get_public_key_previous_version()] [Only two versions assumption] Is the 'at most two versions' constraint enforced at the Storage layer, or can underlying backends violate this causing unexpected behavior? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Function: export_private_key_for_version()] [Historical key access] Should historical key versions be accessible indefinitely, or can this create security risks where compromised old keys can be used to forge historical signatures? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Function: rotate_key()] [Rotation rollback] If rotate_key() fails partway through, is there a rollback mechanism, or can partial rotations leave the storage in an inconsistent state requiring manual recovery? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Line 12: Ed25519 imports] [Weak key detection] Do the Ed25519 operations detect and reject weak or malicious keys (e.g., small subgroup keys, identity element), or can such keys be stored and used? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [All CryptoStorage functions] [Ed25519 signature malleability] Does the implementation use Ed25519 in a way that prevents signature malleability attacks, or can attackers create alternative valid signatures? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Function: sign()] [Ed25519 cofactor clearing] Does the signing implementation properly clear the cofactor for Ed25519, or can small subgroup attacks be exploited? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Function: create_key()] [Ed25519 key generation] Does create_key() use cryptographically secure random number generation for Ed25519 key creation, or can weak RNG be exploited? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [All mutable functions] [Race condition in key operations] Can concurrent calls to create_key(), rotate_key(), and export_private_key() cause race conditions leading to key corruption or loss? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Function: set() and get()] [TOCTOU race] Is there a time-of-check-time-of-use race between get() and set() operations on the same key, allowing attackers to modify keys between read and write? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/storage.rs] [Function: rotate_key()] [Concurrent rotation] Can two threads call rotate_key() on the same key simultaneously, causing double rotation or corrupted key versions? (High)
